2012 Olympics Headquarters

2008 Olympics Recap

Since 1956 and continuing through 2021, Pepperdine has developed a distinguished association with the Olympic Games, as 59 alums associated with Pepperdine Athletics have participated in the Olympics as either a player or a coach.

When the 1984 Summer Games were conducted in metropolitan Los Angeles, Pepperdine's own Raleigh Runnels Memorial Pool served as the venue for the water polo competition.

Waves have won medals in different 17 competitions since 1964, with totals of nine gold, eight silver and six bronze.

Here is a list of which Pepperdine alums have medaled at each Olympics (coaches are not listed since they do not receive medals):

1964 SILVER: USA women's track 4x100 relay (Marilyn White)

SILVER: USA modern pentathlon team (David Kirkwood) 1984 GOLD: USA men's volleyball (Craig Buck)

SILVER: USA women's volleyball (Linda Chisholm)

SILVER: USA men's water polo (Terry Schroeder) 1988 GOLD: USA men's volleyball (Craig Buck, Bob Ctvrtlik, Jeff Stork & Troy Tanner)

SILVER: USA men's water polo (Terry Schroeder)

BRONZE: USA men's tennis singles (Brad Gilbert) 1992 BRONZE: USA men's volleyball (Bob Ctvrtlik & Jeff Stork) 2000 GOLD: USA beach volleyball (Dain Blanton) 2008 GOLD: USA men's volleyball (Sean Rooney)

SILVER: USA men's water polo (Merrill Moses & Jesse Smith)

SILVER: Sweden men's tennis doubles (Simon Aspelin) 2016 BRONZE: USA women's volleyball (Kim Hill) 2020

GOLD: USA women's volleyball (Kim Hill)

BRONZE: Brazil women's tennis doubles (Luisa Stefani)

BRONZE: USA women's soccer (Lynn Williams)

2024 GOLD: USA women's soccer (Lynn Williams)

If coaches did receive medals, however, Pepperdine coaches would add another seven gold medals (Dunphy 1988, 2008 and 2020, Gilbert 1996, Sato 1988, Sicoli 2012, Tanner 2008, Vernovage 2000), four silver medals (Dunphy 2024, Sicoli 2024, Dunphy 2012, Schroeder 2008) and five bronze medals (Jack Kocur 2024, Dunphy 2016, Goorjian 2020, Sato 1992, Sicoli 2016) to the Waves' haul.

GOLD medal On several occasions, Pepperdine athletes have come very close to becoming Olympians but instead wound up as alternates, including: Alvis Andrews USA 1960 Track (triple jump) Jeremy Pope USA 2000 Water Polo Tom Sorensen USA 2000 Volleyball Rod Wilde USA 1984 Volleyball Jonathan Winder USA 2012 Volleyball

Pepperdine alum Harry Nelson, who was on the inaugural football team in 1946, holds the Guinness World Record for most Summer Olympics attended. He went to the Guinness headquarters while in London in 2012 and shot this video:
